Phillip E. Reeves, Esquire, and Jennifer D. Eubanks, both of Gallivan, White

PER CURIAM:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of 
  certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ dismissal of her appeal as untimely.Â  
  Additionally, petitioner has submitted a motion to remand, asking this Court 
  to remand the case to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of our 
  recent decision in Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 602 S.E.2d 
  772 (2004).
Following a jury verdict in favor of respondent, petitioner 
  orally moved for judgment notwithstanding the verdict and a new trial.Â  After 
  the denial of these motions, petitioner unsuccessfully moved to alter or amend 
  the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  Without reaching the merits, the 
  Court of Appeals dismissed petitionerâ€™s appeal as untimely. [1] 
In light of Elam, supra, we find petitionerâ€™s notice of appeal 
  was timely.Â  Accordingly, we grant the petition for a writ of certiorari, dispense 
  with further briefing, reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision, and remand to 
  the Court of Appeals for consideration of the issues on appeal.Â  Petitionerâ€™s 
  motion to remand is denied as moot.
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1]  Arthurs v. Brown, Op. No. 2004-UP-216 (S.C. 
    Ct. App. filed March 30, 2004).

title: Edwards v. State
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
 
   
     
      
        Ricky Dean Edwards, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Horry County
  John Milling, Trial Judge
  Â Paula H. Thomas, Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-072
  Submitted November 29, 2004 â€“ Filed December 20, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, S.C. Office of Appellate 
          Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          Senior Assistant Deputy Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of 
          Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of 
  his application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  The petition is denied on 
  petitionerâ€™s Question 2.
Because there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that 
  petitioner did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, 
  we grant certiorari on petitionerâ€™s Question 1 and proceed with a review of 
  the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 
  S.E.2d 60 (1986).
Before the start of his trial, petitioner made a motion to quash the indictment.Â  
  Petitioner argued the section of the first degree burglary statute that he was 
  being charged under unconstitutionally denied him due process because it allowed 
  his prior crimes to be introduced as elements of first degree burglary. [1] Â  The trial judge denied the motion.Â  
After the first day of trial, petitioner entered a plea of guilty but mentally 
  ill.Â  Trial counsel requested that the plea be accepted subject to petitionerâ€™s 
  right to appeal the constitutionality of the burglary statute; the State did 
  not object.Â  The trial judge accepted the plea and stated, â€œ[T]he appeal will 
  be taken, but he will not be prejudiced with respect to his right to contest 
  the portion of the statute that provides that burglary in the first degree is 
  based upon two prior convictions of burglary or housebreaking, two or more prior 
  convictions.â€Â  
In this State, guilty pleas must be unconditional.Â  State v. Peppers, 
  346 S.C. 502, 552 S.E.2d 288 (2001).Â  If a defendant attempts to attach any 
  condition to a guilty plea, then the trial court should direct a plea of not 
  guilty.Â  State v. Oâ€™Leary, 302 S.C. 17, 393 S.E.2d 186 (1990).Â  It is 
  impermissible for a defendant to preserve constitutional issues while entertaining 
  a guilty plea.Â  Id.Â  If the trial court accepts a conditional guilty 
  plea, then the plea will be vacated on appeal.Â  Peppers, supra.
In our opinion, petitionerâ€™s guilty plea was conditional and was, therefore, 
  invalid.Â  Trial counsel, the State, and the trial judge all acknowledged the 
  conditional nature of petitionerâ€™s guilty plea during the proceeding, yet the 
  plea was still accepted.Â  Accordingly, petitionerâ€™s guilty plea is vacated and 
  the case is remanded for a new trial.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


 [1]  â€œA person is guilty of burglary in the first degree 
  if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a 
  crime in the dwelling, and . . . the burglary is committed by a person with 
  a prior record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a 
  combination of both . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (A)(2) (2003).Â
